sentence: Costco Wholesale (NASDAQ:) has been one of the best stocks of all-time.
Including dividends and spin-offs, Costco stock has returned over 48,000% since its 1985 initial public offering.

Just $10,000 invested in that 1985 IPO today would be worth nearly $5 million today.

Certainly, investors canÃ¢ÂÂt expect quite those same returns going forward.
After all, if Costco delivered that same 19% return for the next decade, its market capitalization would be near $700 billion.
ThatÃ¢ÂÂs more than Walmart (NYSE:) and Home Depot (NYSE:) are worth combined.
That doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean thereÃ¢ÂÂs no upside left in Costco stock.
Admittedly, shares arenÃ¢ÂÂt cheap.
But they shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be.

And with a recent pullback, even including a big bounce in trading on Monday, investors have an opportunity to own one of the marketÃ¢ÂÂs best companies at an attractive Ã¢ÂÂ even discounted Ã¢ÂÂ price.
One of my investment maxims is to choose the leader in an industry.
Ã¢ÂÂCheapÃ¢ÂÂ stocks usually are cheap for good reason.
Investors should pay up for quality rather than trying to buy a struggling, or declining, business.
Overall, itÃ¢ÂÂs hard to argue with the quality of Costco as a business.
It dominates its niche, and bear in mind that Walmart actually beat Costco to the wholesale model.
Its first SamÃ¢ÂÂs Club launched in April 1983, while the original Costco didnÃ¢ÂÂt open until six months later.
However, that hasnÃ¢ÂÂt mattered.
In WalmartÃ¢ÂÂs , SamÃ¢ÂÂs Club generated just under $59 billion in sales.
Additionally, BJÃ¢ÂÂs Wholesale Club (NYSE:) is projected to do about $13 billion over the same period.
Moreover, Costco Ã¢ÂÂ over its last four reported quarters (ending November of last year) Ã¢ÂÂ drove sales of just over $150 billion.
ThatÃ¢ÂÂs more than double the total of its two primary competitors.
That said, CostcoÃ¢ÂÂs edge goes beyond sheer size.
SamÃ¢ÂÂs Club in 2018.
Meanwhile, Costco opened 20 stores in its fiscal 2019, and plans to open Ã¢ÂÂanother 20-ishÃ¢ÂÂ this year, as CFO Richard Galanti put it on the fourth quarter earnings call.
In CostcoÃ¢ÂÂs fiscal first quarter, which ended Nov. 24, excluding fuel.
In WalmartÃ¢ÂÂs fourth quarter, which ended Jan. 31, SamÃ¢ÂÂs Club comparable store sales, excluding fuel and tobacco, rose just 0.8%.
BJÃ¢ÂÂs comparable club sales increased 1.5% in the first three quarters of its fiscal year, and that company reports Q4 on Thursday.
Collectively, Costco is bigger than its rivals and growing faster than them.
Without question, it is the premier operator in the space.
And that alone supports the long-term case for Costco stock.
However, there are two more tailwinds to consider for COST shares.
First, coronavirus fears may actually help near-term sales.
That appears to be driving the bounce in Costco stock on Monday, which ended the day up about 10%.
In other words, nervous consumers are stocking up.
And thereÃ¢ÂÂs no better, or cheaper, place to do so than Costco.
So, while some of those sales may be one-time, Costco may also attract new members over the long haul.
Remember that membership fees, not product sales, drive most of the companyÃ¢ÂÂs profit.
Looking out further, Costco has a massive opportunity in China.
Back in August, I of the companyÃ¢ÂÂs store in Shanghai on my Moneyline podcast.
That opening saw an unbelievable rush of buyers, and the store had to close early and wait times just for parking spots reportedly exceeded three hours.
Moreover, the interest wasnÃ¢ÂÂt just one-time.
The Shanghai location, as of the December earnings call, already had one of the in the entire chain.
Its early success proves that China is a massive opportunity for Costco.
And as more stores open in that market, efficiency will improve Ã¢ÂÂ and so will profit margins.
Combine industry leadership and a massive international opportunity, and thereÃ¢ÂÂs the potential for decades of earnings growth ahead even after an unbelievable 34-year run.
To be sure, investors value Costco stock dearly.
Shares right now trade hands at a whopping 34 times the consensus fiscal 2020 earnings per share estimate.
WMT, HD, Target (NYSE:), and many other quality retailers are available at a cheaper valuation.
But, again, investors should pay up for quality, and for long-term growth potential.

As legendary investor Warren Buffett put it, Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs far better to buy a wonderful company at a fair price than a fair company at a wonderful price.Ã¢ÂÂ

In retail, in particular, with AmazonÃÂ (NASDAQ:) hovering over the entire industry, thereÃ¢ÂÂs been no shortage of fair companies available at wonderful prices.

Most of those prices have only become more Ã¢ÂÂwonderful.Ã¢ÂÂ

Yet, none of those companies are nearly as wonderful as Costco.
The company has grown sales to over $150 billion by delivering value for customers.
And in the process, itÃ¢ÂÂs done the same for shareholders.
Therefore, I see no reason why that should change.
And with COST still trading at a discount to recent highs even after MondayÃ¢ÂÂs gains, thereÃ¢ÂÂs an opportunity to buy on the pullback.
